title: Taeniolabidoidea
text:
Taeniolabidoidea is a group of extinct <a href="mammals">mammals</a> known from <a href="North%20America">North America</a> and <a href="Asia">Asia</a>. They were the largest members of the extinct order <a href="Multituberculata">Multituberculata</a>, as well as the largest non-<a href="theria">theria</a>n mammals. "<a href="Lambdopsalis">Lambdopsalis</a>" even provides direct <a href="fossil">fossil</a> evidence of mammalian <a href="fur">fur</a> in a fairly good state of preservation for a 60-million-year-old animal. Some of these animals were large for their time; "<a href="Taeniolabis">Taeniolabis taoensis</a>" is the largest known multituberculate and though smaller, "<a href="Yubaatar">Yubaatar</a>" is the largest known Mesozoic Asian multituberculate. Average members of the Taeniolaboidea were about <a href="beaver">beaver</a>-sized and the largest even reached sizes comparable to the largest beavers like "<a href="Castoroides">Castoroides</a>", up to about 100 kilograms.
The group was initially established as a <a href="suborder">suborder</a>, before being assigned the rank of a <a href="superfamily%20%28zoology%29">superfamily</a> by McKenna and Bell in 1997 (see Kielan-Jaworowska and Hurum (2001) p. 391-392). Two families are recognised: the primarily North American Taeniolabididae, composed of "<a href="Taeniolabis">Taeniolabis</a>" and "<a href="Kimbetopsalis">Kimbetopsalis</a>", and the exclusively Asian Lambdopsalidae, composed of "<a href="Lambdopsalis">Lambdopsalis</a>", "<a href="Sphenopsalis">Sphenopsalis</a>" and "<a href="Prionessus">Prionessus</a>", with "<a href="Valenopsalis">Valenopsalis</a>" being a basal form outside of either clade. Some of the fossils are well-preserved. Though the possible taeniolabidoid "<a href="Bubodens">Bubodens</a>" is known from the <a href="Lancian">Lancian</a> <a href="Late%20Cretaceous">Late Cretaceous</a> deposits of <a href="South%20Dakota">South Dakota</a>, and "<a href="Yubaatar">Yubaatar</a>" is known from Late Cretaceous deposits in the <a href="Henan%20Province">Henan Province</a>, the clade is otherwise only clearly represented in <a href="Paleocene">Paleocene</a> <a href="Stratum">strata</a>.
Derived characteristics of the <a href="taxon">taxon</a> (apomorphies) include: "snout short and wide with anterior part of <a href="zygomatic%20arch">zygomatic arch</a>es directed transversely, resulting in a square-like shape of the skull (shared with <a href="Kogaionidae">Kogaionidae</a>); frontals small, pointed posteriorly, almost or completely excluded from the orbital rim," (Kielan-Jaworowska and Hurum 2001, p. 417).
